On Friday, March 6th, members of the Byron-Bergen FFA and faculty adviser Jeff Parnapy distributed twenty $5 Dunkin’ Donuts gift cards to the winners of the 2020 FFA Coloring Contest. Students in grades Pre-K through 4 were inviting to participate. Coloring sheets featured agricultural themes like produce and farm animals and varied in difficulty depending on grade level. The completed work of one student from each participating classroom was chosen and that student was awarded a gift card and a round of applause from their classmates.
“This contest was a way to introduce younger student to the FFA,” said Parnapy. “I want the students to associate the FFA with agriculture and farming. I also want them to associate the FFA with fun, because we have a lot of fun. I hope they will all be inspired to join!”

Please join us in wishing Grace Jack a happy retirement. After 25 years with the Byron-Bergen Central School District, today is her last day. She began her career part-time as a Cafeteria Monitor then, after three years, became a 1-to-1 Aide, transitioning to full-time.
“The teachers that I’ve worked with have always been amazing. I enjoy the kids. I’ve never considered my job a ‘job’. I love to come to work every day. Everyone here has touched my life in so many ways. I hope I made a difference in the lives of the children and they’ll forever be in my heart.”
In retirement, Jack plans to travel including an upcoming trip to Hawai’i.

On Tuesday, December 17, the Senior High School musicians closed out the 2019 season with style. As the community gathered, they were serenaded by the Byron-Bergen Jazz Trio playing holiday music arranged for them by Elementary School Music Teacher and jazz musician Bob Lancia.

Under the direction of Laurence Tallman, the Senior Chorale performed six pieces of music including traditional holiday classics and a selection from Disney's Frozen.

The Singing Silhouettes then took to the stage with a selection of music from around the globe including songs in Spanish, Hebrew, Norwegian, and Hawaiian. They also performed Mr. Tallman's original arrangement of "Must the Winter Come So Soon" from the opera Vanessa.

The Concert Band, led by Kevin Bleiler, closed out the evening with five pieces including a song for Hanukkah and lively performance of Sleigh Ride complete with a visitor from the North Pole.

Bravo!

The 92nd National FFA Convention included at tribute to 50 years of FFA membership for young women. Students toured the FFA career expo and agricultural college career fair, attended a Brett Young concert and a rodeo.

On Friday, November 1, the Merry-Go-Round Youth Theatre visited the fourth grade classes with a special presentation for #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth. "The Keeper’s Voice" is an experiential production in which the students act as the Haudenosaunee people to educate two fictional visitors on the lives and cultural traditions of the five nations in the mid-1800s.

The story is guided forward by Matilda Joslyn Gage, a real-life scholar, suffragist, abolitionist, and Haudenosaunee ally who was eventually adopted by the Mohawk Wolf Clan. In the play, the character of Matilda brings a reporter and a college professor to a meeting of the five nations to show how Haudenosaunee culture could influence the civil rights in 19th century United States culture.

During the presentation, the students discussed Haudenosaunee cultural beliefs such as the advantages of peace among the nations, having an active role in government, and equality.

Students were also able to take part in hands-on activities including building circuits using natural electrolytes in fruits and vegetables and creating structures out of sticks capable of supporting bricks.
After the visit, one student commented, “I never wanted to go to college until today. Now, I definitely want to go.”

After the visit, one student commented, “I never wanted to go to college until today. Now, I definitely want to go.”
